material.mattext: The fact that the p-value=.002 means that:
There is .002 probability of observing data like that observed.
There is .002 probability of that 50% of US adults oppose gay marriage.
There is a probability of .002 (i.e., very unlikely) to observe data like that observed if the proportion of US adults who oppose gay marriage were 50%.
There is .998 probability that the majority of US adults oppose gay marriage.
Incorrect. While it is true that the p-value is the probability of observing data like that observed, but it is calculated assuming that the null hypothesis, Ho, is true.

Incorrect. Recall that the p-value is the probability of observing data like that observed assuming that the null hypothesis, Ho, is true. Actually, the statement that you chose is statistically wrong. Note that the proportion of US adults who oppose gay marriage is a parameter (p), and therefore a fixed, unknown quantity which we are doing inference about. You can talk about the probability that a random variable takes a certain value(s), but not about the probability that a fixed quantity takes a certain value(s). In the next activity, this issue will come up again.
Good Job! Indeed, the p-value is the probability of observing data like that observed assuming that the null hypothesis, Ho, is true.

Incorrect. Recall that the p-value is the probability of observing data like that observed assuming that the null hypothesis, Ho, is true. Actually, the statement that you chose is statistically wrong. Note that the proportion of US adults who oppose gay marriage is a parameter (p), and therefore a fixed, unknown quantity which we are doing inference about. You can talk about the probability that a random variable takes a certain value(s), but not about the probability of a fixed quantity taking a certain value(s).
